case_name: William Jacks Co. Employees Union, Madras v. William Jacks Co. Ltd., Madras

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1700 of 1968 is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No, 1700 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 9, 1968 of the Industrial Tribunal, Madras in Industrial Dispute No. II of 1957. K. Ramamurthi, I. Ramamurthy, Vineet Kumar and Shyamala Pappu, for the appellants.

facts.text: Award dated March 9, 1968 of the Industrial Tribunal, Madras in Industrial Dispute No. II of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 9, 1968 of the Industrial Tribunal, Madras in Industrial Dispute No. II of 1957. K. Ramamurthi, I. Ramamurthy, Vineet Kumar and Shyamala Pappu, for the appellants. C. Chagla and D. N. Gupta for the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant is William Jacks Co. Employees Union, Madras, representing workmen employed by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in the appeal is the employer, William Jacks Co. Ltd., Madras, while the appellant is the William Jacks Co. Employees Union, Madras, representing the workmen employed by the respondent.

facts.text: Dispute relates to payment of bonus for calendar years 1964 and 1965 under Payment of Bonus Act, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against an Award of the Industrial Tribunal, Madras, in a dispute relating to payment of bonus under the Payment of Bonus Act, 1965  No. 21 of 1965   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Appellant claimed bonus at 20% of annual wages for 1964 and 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that, for the two calendar years 1964 and 1965, the workmen were entitled to bonus at the maximum rate of 20 per cent of their annual wages while the respondent Co.

facts.text: Respondent claimed no available surplus, liability only minimum 4% of wages for 1964 and 1965.

anchor.surface_text: put forward the case that there was numberavailable surplus and, companysequently, the liability to pay bonus for these two years companyld number exceed the minimum of 4 per cent of the wages.

facts.text: Respondent is branch of William Jacks Co. Ltd. registered in England with Head Office in London.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the respondent Co. is a Bench of, William Jacks Co. Ltd. registered in England with its Head Office in London.

facts.text: Company has three offices in India: Calcutta (Regional Head Office), Bombay, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in India this Company has three offices. One is in Calcutta which also functions at the Regional Head Office for all the three Branches in India. The other two Branches are in Bombay and in Madras,

facts.text: Company filed balance-sheets, profit and loss account, calculations of available surplus showing no surplus.

anchor.surface_text: During the hearing of the reference before the Tribunal, the Company filed its balance-sheets, profits, and loss account, and calculations of available surplus in accordance with the provisions of the Act

facts.text: Tribunal accepted Company's calculations and based award on them.

anchor.surface_text: These calculations were challenged on various grounds before the Tribunal, but numbere of them was accepted and the Award was based on the calculations filed on behalf of the Company.

facts.text: Appellant challenged calculations in respect of seven different items.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal before us, learned companynsel appearing on behalf of the appellant has challenged the calculations in respect of seven different items,

facts.text: Direct commission of Rs. 40,000 estimated received by London Office for Madras Branch.

anchor.surface_text: The first claim on behalf of the appellant was that there should be an add back of an estimated sum of Rs. 40,000 / which was received as direct companymission paid by the manufac- turers to the London Office

facts.text: In 1964, commission Rs. 8,80,504/- and 1965 Rs. 7,46,391/- includes direct commission.

anchor.surface_text: In 1964, the sum of Rs. 8,80,504/- and, in 1965, the sum of Rs. 7,46,391/include the direct companymission. According to his evidence, therefore, the direct companymission has already been taken into account

facts.text: Handling charges included by London Head Office in invoices for goods sent to Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The second item claimed is add back in respect of handling charges which were included by the London Head Office in the invoices for goods sent to Madras.

facts.text: Directors and General Managers Office expenses in Calcutta: Rs. 44,768/- for 1964 and Rs. 50,848/- for 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The third item is in respect of the Directors and General Managers Office expenses in Calcutta amounting to Rs. 44,768/for the year 1964 and Rs. 50,848 - for the year 1965.

facts.text: Interest charged by London Office: Rs. 1,00,657/- for 1964 and Rs. 1,65,255/- for 1965 on advances to Madras Branch.

anchor.surface_text: relates to the question of interest charged by the London Office. in the sum of Rs. 1,00,657 for 1964 and Rs. 1,65,255/- for 1965 on advances made by the London Office to this Branch at Madras during these years.

facts.text: Court holds interest paid by Branch to Head Office is not legitimate expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that these amounts have been paid by the Branch at Madras to Head Office in London and represent interest which the London Office demanded from the Madras Branch

facts.text: Jax Board Factory expenses: Rs. 11,747/- in 1964 and Rs. 7,251/- in 1965, factory had no production but did not cease functioning.

anchor.surface_text: The fifth objection relates to a sum of Rs. 11,747/- in 1964 and Rs. 7,251/- in 1965 shown as expenses incurred in the Jax Board Factory on the ground that the Jax Board Factory had ceased to function

facts.text: Provision for gratuity and contingencies: for accrued liabilities, not reserves.

anchor.surface_text: The sixth claim on behalf of the appellant is that the provision for gratuity and other companytingencies should also be added back as representing other reserves under item 2 c  of the Second Schedule

facts.text: Income-tax calculated without taking into account bonus payable.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the amount of income-tax shown as expenditure has been calculated without taking into account the bonus which would be payable to the workmen under the award.

facts.text: Court directs add back of interest Rs. 1,00,657/- for 1964 and Rs. 1,65,255/- for 1965, amend available surplus.

anchor.surface_text: the two sums of Rs. 1,00,657/- for 1964 and Rs. 1,65,255/- for 1965 must be added back on the basis that they are wrongly shown as expenditure deductible in calculating profit and loss.

facts.text: Leave calculation to the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We leave this calculation to the Tribunal.

facts.text: Witness M.W.1 Thiru S.S. Mani stated direct commission credited in Branch accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The only evidence on this point is found in the statement of the Companys witness, M. W. 1, Thiru S. S. Mani, who stated that the direct companymission received by this Company relating to this Branch

facts.text: No cross-examination on direct commission point by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercross-examination on this point on behalf of the appellant, number has any evidence been led by the appellant to show that the statement of this witness is incorrect.
Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 9, 1968 of the Industrial Tribunal, Madras in Industrial Dispute No. II of 1957.

This appeal by special leave is directed against an Award of the Industrial Tribunal, Madras, in a dispute relating to payment of bonus under the Payment of Bonus Act, 1965  No. 21 of 1965   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

Payment of Bonus Act, 1965  No. 21 of 1965   hereinafter referred to as the Act . The respondent in the appeal is the employer, William Jacks Co. Ltd., Madras, while the appellant is the William Jacks Co. Employees Union, Madras, representing the workmen employed by the respondent.

holdings.text: In the circumstances, this claim has to be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: There is no cross-examination on this point on behalf of the appellant, no has any evidence been led by the appellant to show that the statement of this witness is incorrect. In the circumstances, this claim has to be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witness evidence unchallenged that direct commission already credited in branch accounts and included in commission head of profit and loss.

holdings.text: Consequently, there can arise no question of making any addition in respect of these handling charges while calculating gross profit.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it is clear that these handling charges have no connection with the administrative overhead expenses of the Head office which are taken into account under item 6 e of the Second Schedule. The actual expenses incurred by various Commercial Departments of the Company in England in handling the particular goods are added in the invoices to the cost of those goods and are realised as part of the sale price.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Handling charges are recoverable from customers as part of sale price, not expenditure or admin overhead under item 6(e); witness evidence clear, no cross-examination.

holdings.text: In the circumstances, this objection also fails.

anchor.surface_text: These sums which have been shown as expenses in the accounts in the Madras Branch are amounts allocable to that Branch. This has been again proved by the same witness, M. W. 1, Mani. There is no cross-examination and no evidence to show that the case put forward by him is incorrect. In the circumstances, this objection also fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Calcutta office expenses are allocable administrative overhead similar to London; proved by unchallenged witness evidence.

holdings.text: In calculation of the gross profit for purposes of bonus, therefore, the two sums of Rs. 1,00,657/- for 1964 and Rs. 1,65,255/- for 1965 must be added back on the basis that they are wrongly shown as expenditure deductible in calculating profit and loss.

anchor.surface_text: the two sums of Rs. 1,00,657/- for 1964 and Rs. 1,65,255/- for 1965 must be added back on the basis that they are wrongly shown as expenditure deductible in calculating profit and loss.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No creditor-debtor relationship between head office and branch of same company; interest is internal transfer, not legitimate expenditure; supported by proviso to Third Schedule item 1 excluding such as liabilities; s23 presumption limited.

anchor.surface_text: The expenses are actual expenses in the factory during those two years as certified by the Auditors and there is no material on the basis of which it can be held that these expenses were not incurred. This objection, therefore, fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factory had no production but not ceased functioning; expenses actual and certified by auditors; no material to disprove.

holdings.text: Such provision is, therefore, not a reserve at all and cannot be added back under item 2 c of the Second Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Such provision is, therefore, not a reserve at all and cannot be added back under item 2 c of the Second Schedule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions for accrued known liabilities like gratuity based on service rendered are charges against profits, not reserves; follows Metal Box and Companies Act Sch VI definitions.

holdings.text: This ground of challenge also, therefore, fails.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, there is no reason for us to differ from the view expressed by this Court in Metal Box case. This ground of challenge also, therefore, fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income-tax calculated ignoring bonus per Metal Box; Amendment Act 1969 makes no substantial change to ss 6(c),7; not parliamentary exposition altering precedent.

holdings.text: The presumption under section 23 is confined to the accuracy of the statements and particulars contained in the balance-sheet and the profit and loss account. If any item in the accounts is wrongly shown as expenditure when, on the face of it, it is not so, the Court is not bound to hold that the method adopted in preparing the accounts is correct simply because the auditors raised no objection.

anchor.surface_text: The presumption under section 23 is confined to the accuracy of the statements and particulars contained in the balance-sheet and the profit and loss account. If any item in the accounts is wrongly shown as expenditure when, on the face of it, it is not so,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption limited to arithmetical accuracy; court can examine if item wrongly classified as expenditure despite audit.

holdings.text: No relationship of creditor and debtor can exist between two different Offices of the same Company.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that these amounts have been paid by the Branch at Madras to Head Office in London and represent interest which the London Office demanded from the Madras Branch

holdings.reasoning_summary: Head office and branch are same entity; advances internal, interest not genuine expenditure.

holdings.text: As a result, we hold that the Tribunal was right in accepting the calculations made by the Company, except in respect of the interest paid on advances made by the Head Office to the Branch at Madras. The interest shown as expenditure in the accounts has to be added back... and the available surplus... must be amended accordingly. We leave this calculation to the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: As a result, we hold that the Tribunal was right in accepting the calculations made by the Company, except in respect of the interest paid on advances made by the Head Office to the Branch at Madras. The interest shown as expenditure in the accounts has to be added back, as indicated by us above, and the available surplus for purposes of calculation of the bonus payable as well as for purposes of set on or set off must be amended accordingly. We leave this calculation to the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges rejected except interest add back; tribunal award upheld otherwise; remit for recalculation of surplus/bonus.
